Celery is only used for the SQL Lab backend at the moment, when switched on. We may turn it on outside of SQL Lab eventually.

This is in part for historic reasons, but while we assume SQL Lab can be used for "long running queries" (minutes, even hours) in our case against Hive or Presto, these queries may create summary tables to power interactive exploring or dashboarding.

It's generally not a good experience to have long running queries in the explore view where people assume interactivity, or to have a dashboard that takes forever to load (though with caching it's a different story). 

In the meantime you may be able to crank up your web server timeouts.

Note that currently we only build and run continuous integration tests against 2.7 and 3.4.

If the community wants to use 3.5 (and mayyyybe 3.6) I'd be willing to add 3.5 to accept a PR that does that, and fixes 3.5 build issues if any.

Thanks for your replies. While it's not very challenging to create a Gunicorn startup script to allow Superset to be served from a socket, I think it's a common enough set up to warrant having runserver (or the Superset config file) accept a path to a UNIX socket for the sake of consistency and simplicity. So I've added a pull request: https://github.com/airbnb/superset/pull/2627

Looks reasonable and prudent to me - LGTM!

I do think that it's necessary to also include a prompt upon saving if the saver != owner (I'm not sure we currently have 'owners' for a data source). The prompt might say something along the lines of, 
_"Note: You are altering and overwriting the datasource definition. All associated slices may be affected."_

Celery is only required where `Allow Run Async` is checked. Knowing that a typical web request timeout is < 1 minute, you need to run queries outside of a web request scope if you want to run queries that take longer than that. And with connections to databases like Impala, Presto or Hive, you typically want that. For small OLTP-type applications, you can usually get away with the non-async setup. If you check `Allow Run Async`, it assumes you have Celery setup. Essentially this means that you have configured a message queue and starter one or many `superset worker` processes.

Here's the related pyhive logic:
https://github.com/dropbox/PyHive/blob/59746c31f1b16c96e90a5dd2cb00e23b30d3caea/pyhive/hive.py#L91
Merged

@superibra @hungrytortoise @mistercrunch , I guess the pyhive package only support python2.7, not support python 3.

**https://pypi.python.org/pypi/PyHive/0.2.1**
Requirements

Install using

pip install pyhive[hive] for the Hive interface and
pip install pyhive[presto] for the Presto interface.
PyHive works with

Python 2.7
For Presto: Presto install
For Hive: HiveServer2 daemon
There’s also a third party Conda package.
